title: Tongeren Group
text:
The Tongeren Group is a <a href="lithostratigraphy">lithostratigraphic</a> unit (a sequence of <a href="stratum">rock strata</a>) in the <a href="Subsurface%20%28geology%29">subsurface</a> of <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>. It consists of shallow marine, <a href="epicontinental">epicontinental</a> and/or <a href="continent">continental</a> <a href="clay">clay</a>s and <a href="sand">sand</a>s from the late <a href="Eocene">Eocene</a> to early <a href="Oligocene">Oligocene</a> <a href="Epoch%20%28geology%29">epoch</a>s (between 37 and 30 million years old). 
The Belgian Tongeren Group correlates with the <a href="Netherlands">Dutch</a> <a href="Tongeren%20Formation">Tongeren Formation</a>. The name was introduced by <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20Hubert%20Dumont">André Hubert Dumont</a> in 1849.

Stratigraphic relations.
In northwest Belgium the Tongeren Group (represented in that area mostly by the Zelzate Formation) is stratigraphically lying on top of the <a href="Maldegem%20Formation">Maldegem Formation</a> (middle Eocene clay and sand). This formation is lacking in the east of the country, where the Tongeren Group is found directly on top of rocks with older ages, like the <a href="Landen%20Group">Landen Group</a>.
The Tongeren Group is usually overlain by deposits of the late Oligocene <a href="Rupel%20Group">Rupel Group</a>.
